009package imagingbook.common.util.tuples;
010
011/**
012 * <p>
013 * Elementary implementation of tuples, i.e, ordered sequences
014 * of items of arbitrary types.
015 * Tuples are generally immutable and their main use is to get methods
016 * return multiple values with maximum compile-time safety.
017 * A concrete tuple class is defined for
018 * each "arity", e.g., {@link Tuple2} for 2 elements.
019 * Currently tuple classes for 2, 3 and 4 elements are defined.
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * A tuple may be instantiated using either the class constructor, e.g.,
023 * </p>
024 * <pre>new Tuple2&lt;Integer, String&gt;(10, "Foo")</pre>
025 * <p>
026 * or the associated static method
027 * </p>
028 * <pre>Tuple2.of(10, "Foo")</pre>
029 * Individual tuple elements can be accessed (read-only) by the associated
030 * field names, e.g. {@code f0}, {@code f1} ... etc.
031 * There are no getter methods.
032 * @author WB
033 *
034 */
035public interface Tuple {
036        
037        
038        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
039        
040//      public static void main(String[] args) {
041//              Tuple2<Integer, String> tA = new Tuple2<>(10, "Foo");
042//              Tuple tB = new Tuple2<Integer, String>(-3, "Bar");
043//              Tuple tC = Tuple2.from(17, "Kaputnik");
044//              System.out.println("tA = " + tA.toString());
045//              System.out.println("tB = " + tB.toString());
046//              System.out.println("tC = " + tC.toString());
047//              
048//              int k = tA.get0();
049//              String s = tA.get1();
050//              
051//              System.out.println("tA.f0 = " + tA.get0().toString());
052//              System.out.println("tA.f1 = " + tA.get1().toString());
053//              
054//              System.out.println("tA class = " + tA.getClass());
055//              System.out.println("tB class = " + tB.getClass());
056//              System.out.println("tC class = " + tC.getClass());
057//      }
058}
